history.content: Although I am not on a grad school admissions team, I would be shocked if a C+ in a breadth class taken at a CC or even Berkeley itself would be the reason you don't get into graduate school assuming you have good grades in core classes and relevant research/professional experience, but it might be looked at if you're somewhere on the edge potentially, although again probably not as much as other things

I doubt it will make or break your application if you have great grades in core classes at Berkeley and relevant research/professional experience etc. Although I am not on a grad school admissions team, I would be shocked if a C+ in a breadth class taken at a CC (let alone Berkeley for that matter) would be the reason you don't get in, but it might be looked at if you're somewhere on the edge potentially, although again probably not as much as other things

children.subject: When I was applying to grad school I'm pretty sure they wanted all transcripts ie including non Berkeley ones
Is this the same for the 5th year master's here at Berkeley?

Yes. When you're applying to grad school, you're required to submit all of your college transcripts. This includes your application for the 5th year MS. Berkeley also asks you to compute your GPA for your first two years and then your GPA for your last two years separately (some programs ask you to break out your tech GPA).

If you just have the one C+ on there, and it's in a course that's not relevant to your planned degree, then it's not going to prevent you from getting into grad school. If you consistently get low grades in your breadth courses, then that could be a problem for top schools like Berkeley. I've read applications for M.Eng., and we overlook single aberrations, but not patterns unless you explain it as something that happened to you during a particular period (e.g., I got bad grades during Spring 2019 because xxx.).
are they gonna need my transcript for admissions purposes, or just the berkeley transcript?
<md>They typically just overlook it if its a single irrelevant course.</md>

history.content: I'm taking a breadth class at a cc, and wondering if getting a C+ will affect me negatively in future grad school admissions? I know it won't count for my berkeley gpa but not sure if you need to send over transcripts for every school you've attended. I'm new to the whole cc thing and have a fear that if I try to pnp it, I'll do something wrong and I won't get credit for it at berkeley lol
history.subject: do grad schools care about grades in breadth classes taken at cc?
